"J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@...> wrote on 09.04.2004 18:42:35:

> jsa@... wrote:
> > Is the number returned by Test.countTestCases() binding? 
> 
> I don't understand the way you're using the word "binding" here. 
> countTestCases() counts the number of test cases in a suite. For a 
> single TestCase object, it answers 1; for a TestSuite, it counts the 
> Test objects it contains, recursively.

I meant to ask wether the number returned by countTestCases() is only used 
for displaying progress bars and other niceties or if returning a 
wrong/invalid value here will actually break my TestSuite. (to which 
Michael Silverstein already answered, thanks).

> > Do current TestRunners depend on a pre-defined
> > structure of the test?
> 
> I don't understand what this question means.

Hm ... let me try to re-phrase:

All test-suites I've seen thus far have a very clearly defined hierarchy 
of tests (that is either hand-coded using suite()-methods or generated by 
some kind of find-all-test-cases-in-this-hierarchy-algorithm). In my 
little Junit-misuse experiment I don't have such pre-defined hierarchy but 
only decide which tests need to be run when running them (so one test 
might dynamically add 3 other tests that need to be run).

I just wanted to know if there are any basic problems with this approach 
that I should consider.

regards
Joachim Sauer
